resources.string: We provide services to parents who has an Autistic child. shuch as Screening, Games, Helpful tips and more… Start Now!
We just need your registered Email to send you password reset instructions
Click on the button below to add an alarm
He/She often notices small sounds when others do not
He/She usually concentrates more on the whole picture rather than the small details
In a social group ,He/She can easily keep track of several different peoples conversations
He/She finds it easy to go back and fourth between different activities
He/She does not know how to keep a conversation going with his/her peers
He/She is good at social chit-chat
When He/She reads a story,he finds it difficult to work out the character s intenons or feelings
When He/She was in preschool,he/she used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children
He/She finds it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face
He/She finds it hard to make new friends
Enter age of your child (in years)
Was your child born with jaundice?
Has anyone in the immediate family been diagnosed with autism?
HOW CAN WE TAKE CARE OF YOUR CHILD?
please check your email for the confirmation code
authorization failed, please log in again
Your email or password is incorrect
I have confirmation code for new password
I have code for new E-mail
Password length should be at least 8 characters,digits and letters
Choose one of the folloing tests.

The Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers, is a screener that will ask a series of 20 questions about your child’s behavior. It\'s intended for toddlers between 16 and 30 months of age. The results will let you know if a further evaluation may be needed. You can use the results of the screener to discuss any concerns that you may have with your child’s healthcare provider.
1.If you point at something across the room, does your child look at it? (For Example, if you point at a toy or an animal, does your child look at the toy or animal?)
2.Have you ever wondered if your child might be deaf?
3.Does your child play pretend or make-believe? (For Example, pretend to drink from an empty cup, pretend to talk on a phone, or pretend to feed a doll or stuffed animal?)
4.Does your child like climbing on things? (For Example, furniture, playground equipment, or stairs)
5.Does your child make unusual finger movements near his or her eyes? (For Example, does your child wiggle his or her fingers close to his or her eyes?)
6.Does your child point with one finger to ask for something or to get help? (For Example, pointing to a snack or toy that is out of reach)
7.Does your child point with one finger to show you something interesting? (For Example, pointing to an airplane in the sky or a big truck in the road)
8.s your child interested in other children? (For Example, does your child watch other children, smile at them, or go to them?)
9.Does your child show you things by bringing them to you or holding them up for you to see — not to get help, but just to share? (For Example, showing you a flower, a stuffed animal, or a toy truck)
10.Does your child respond when you call his or her name? (For Example, does he or she look up, talk or babble, or stop what he or she is doing when you call his or her name?)
11.When you smile at your child, does he or she smile back at you?
12.Does your child get upset by everyday noises? (For Example, does your child scream or cry to noise such as a vacuum cleaner or loud music?)
14.Does your child look you in the eye when you are talking to him or her, playing with him or her, or dressing him or her?
15.Does your child try to copy what you do? (For Example, wave bye-bye, clap, or make a funny noise when you do)
16.If you turn your head to look at something, does your child look around to see what you are looking at?
Does your child try to get you to watch him or her? (For Example, does your child look at you for praise, or say “look” or “watch me”?)
Does your child understand when you tell him or her to do something? (For Example, if you don\'t point, can your child understand “put the book on the chair” or “bring me the blanket”?)

19.If something new happens, does your child look at your face to see how you feel about it? (For Example, if he or she hears a strange or funny noise, or sees a new toy, will he or she look at your face?)
20.Does your child like movement activities? (For Example, being swung or bounced on your knee)
Please make sure to answer all questions!
The score indicates low risk, but if your child is younger than 24 months, or you have other concerns you should talk to your doctor about rescreening.
The score indicates medium risk. This means you should to take your child to his or her doctor for a follow-up screening. You can also seek early intervention services for your child.
Score indicates high risk. This means you should to take your child to his or her doctor for a full evaluation. You should also begin early intervention services for your child.

The Gilliam Autism Rating Scale-2 (GARS-2) is a 42 item norm-referenced screening instrument used for the assessment of individuals ages 3-22 who have severe behavioral problems that may be indicative of autism. Its purpose is to identify Autism Spectrum Disorders, It is important to clarify that this is not a medical diagnosis. The GARS-2 gathers information about specific characteristics typically noted in children with autism spectrum disorders in three areas (Stereotyped Behaviors, Communication, and Social Interaction).
Avoids establishing eye contact, looks away when eye contact is made.
Stares at hands, objects, or items in the environment for at least 5 seconds.
Rapidly flicks fingers or hands in front of eyes for periods of 5 seconds or more.
Eats specific foods and refuses to eat what most people will usually eat.
Licks, tastes or attempts to eat inedible objects.
Spins objects not designed for spinning.
Rocks back and forth while seated or standing.
Makes rapid lunging, darting movement when moving from place to place.
Flaps hand or fingers in front of the face or at sides.
Makes high-pitched sounds or other vocalizations for self-stimulation.
Slaps, hits, or bites self or attempts to injure self in other ways.
Repeats (echoes) words verbally or with signs.
Repeats words or phrases over and over.
Speaks or signs with flat tone.
Looks away or avoids looking at the speaker when his/her name is called.
Does not ask for things he or she wants.
Does not initiate conversations with peers or adults.
Repeats unintelligible sounds over and over.
Uses gestures instead of speech or signs to obtain objects.
Inappropriately answers questions about a statement or brief story.
Avoids eye contact and looks away when someone looks at him or her.
Stares or looks unhappy or unexcited when praised, humored or entertained.
Does not imitate other people when imitation is required or desirable, such as in games or learning activities.
Withdraws, remains aloof, or acts standoffish in group situations.
Behaves in an unreasonably fearful, frightened manner.
Is unaffectionate, doesn’t give affectionate responses.
Shows no recognition that a person is present (ie: looks through people)
Becomes upset when routines are changed.
Responds negatively or with temper tantrums when given commands, requests, or directions.
Lines up objects in a precise, orderly fashion and becomes upset when the order is disturbed.

The following test is a 35 seconds video played for your child and his reaction will be recorded, please make sure that the device is on landscape mode and well fixed in front of the child, it\'s preferred to make the child sit in a clear background with a minimum amount of movement. Please make sure that the child\'s face is clearly visible to the front camera.
Please keep the device on landscape mode
This result indicates low risk. However, if you are still worried you should check with a doctor.
This result indicates medium risk. It\'s required to repeat the test after 2 weeks or to check with a doctor.
This result indicates high risk. It\'s required to check with a doctor immediately.
Does the child mind being hugged?
Does the child like to spin around himself?
Does he/she arrange his toys in order behind each other?
Does he/she always prefer to sleep on the cold floor?
Is he/she always attached to one specific toy other than the others?
Does the child get annoyed by loud noises exaggeratedly?
This result indicates a low risk of autism, nothing to worry about, but you can check with a doctor if you are still concerned.
This result indicates a medium risk of autism, you need to re-run the test after 2 weeks, or check with a doctor if you are concerned.
This result indicates a high risk of autism, we strongly encourage you to proceed to the next test.
The result will be available soon
If you didn\'t complete the test, the result will be gone.
Please let the app access your location
The following test is designed to determine a child\'s ability to understand emotions

"An image representing an emotion will appear for 3 seconds, once it appears the child must imitate the same emotion with his face so the camera can capture it, then press next to display the next image. the child face must be at a distance of at least 60cm from the device "
The following test is designed to measure the child reflexes and ability to focus.
A red dot will appear on the screen, the child is asked to press the dot as fast as possible. the dot will appear 5 times on the screen.
The following service requires internet connection and location services, it\'s advised to give these permissions to the app.
Please give the app location permission.
Dream School for Model Education (for people with special needs and learning difficulties)
Ahmed Orabi Association - Line 2 North - Plot 5047
Happy World School (Alaa Foundation for Special Needs)
Carrefour main road - next to Zahraa Maadi Youth Center
Al Yusr School for Special Cases (Early Intervention - Academic Delay - Cerebral Palsy - Autism - Learning Difficulties)
